{{other uses}} {{EngvarB|date=June 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox scientist | name = David Harvey | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=GBR|FBA|size=100%}} | image = David Harvey2.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1935|10|31|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Gillingham, Kent]], England | death_date = | nationality = British | workplaces = City University of New York | alma_mater = [[St John's College, Cambridge]] | thesis_title = Aspects of agricultural and rural change in Kent, 1800–1900 | thesis_year = 1961 | fields = [[Geography]], [[social theory]], [[political economy]] | known_for = [[Marxist geography]], [[Quantitative revolution|quantitative revolution in geography]], [[critical geography]], [[right to the city]],
[[Time space compression]], [[Accumulation by dispossession]] | influences = [[Karl Marx|Marx]], [[Henri Lefebvre|Lefebvre]], [[Friedrich Engels|Engels]], [[Murray Bookchin|Bookchin]], [[Antonio Gramsci|Gramsci]], [[R. Radhakrishnan|Radhakrishnan]] | influenced = [[Neil Smith (geographer)|Neil Smith]], [[Andy Merrifield]], [[Erik Swyngedouw]], [[Miguel Robles-Durán]], the development of [[Marxist geography]], [[critical geography]] and [[human geography]] as a discipline }} '''David W. Harvey''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|FBA}} (born 31 October 1935) is the [[Distinguished Professor]] of [[anthropology]] and [[geography]] at the [[Graduate Center of the City University of New York]] ([[CUNY]]). He received his PhD in geography from the [[University of Cambridge]] in 1961. Harvey has authored many books and essays that have been prominent in the development of modern geography as a [[academic discipline|discipline]]. He is a proponent of the idea of the [[right to the city]]. In 2007, Harvey was listed as the 18th most-cited author of books in the humanities and social sciences in that year, as established by counting cites from academic journals in the [[Thomson Reuters ISI database]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/most-cited-authors-of-books-in-the-humanities-2007/405956.article|title=Most cited authors of books in the humanities, 2007|date=2009-03-26|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2017-10-10|language=en | subscription = yes}} Some of the artists influenced by Harvey's work are [[Elisheva Levy]] in Israel and [[Theaster Gates]] in Chicago. ==Background== [[File:Class 12 Reading Marx's Capital Vol 2 with David Harvey.webm|thumb|David Harvey lecturing a class]] Harvey attended [[The Howard School, Kent|Gillingham Grammar School for Boys]] and [[St John's College, Cambridge]] (for both his undergraduate and post-graduate studies). Harvey's early work, beginning with his PhD (on hops production in 19th century Kent), was historical in nature, emerging from a regional-historical tradition of inquiry widely used at Cambridge and in Britain at that time. Historical inquiry runs through his later works (for example on Paris). Harvey resides in New York. He has a daughter Delfina born in January, 1990.https://soundcloud.com/freshed-podcast/freshed-100-a-marxist-critique-of-higher-education-david-harvey ==Life and work== {{American socialism |expanded=Theorists}} [[File:David Harvey on Subversive Festival.jpg|thumb|right|David Harvey at [[Subversive Festival]]]] By the mid-1960s, Harvey followed trends in the social sciences to employ quantitative methods, contributing to spatial science and [[Positivism|positivist]] theory. Roots of this work were visible while he was at Cambridge: the [[Department of Geography, University of Cambridge|Department of Geography]] also housed [[Richard Chorley]], and [[Peter Haggett]]. His ''[[Explanation in Geography]]'' (1969) was a landmark text in the methodology and philosophy of geography, applying principles drawn from the philosophy of science in general to the field of geographical knowledge. But after its publication Harvey moved on again, to become concerned with issues of [[social inequality|social injustice]] and the nature of the capitalist system itself. He has never returned to embrace the arguments made in ''Explanation'', but still he conforms to the critique of absolute space and exceptionalism in geography of the regional-historical tradition that he saw as an outcome of Kantian ''synthetic [[a priori and a posteriori|a priori]]'' knowledge. Moving from [[Bristol University]] to [[Johns Hopkins University]] in [[Baltimore]] in the USA, he positioned himself centrally in the newly emerging field of radical and [[Marxist geography]]. [[social injustice|Injustice]], [[racism]], and [[Exploitation of labour|exploitation]] were visible in Baltimore, and activism around these issues was tangible in early 1970s [[Northeastern United States|East Coast]], perhaps more so than in Britain. The journal ''Antipode'' was formed at [[Clark University]]; Harvey was one of the first contributors. The Boston [[Association of American Geographers]] meetings in 1971 were a landmark, with Harvey and others disrupting the traditional approach of their peers. In 1972, in a famous essay on ghetto formation, he argued for the creation of "revolutionary theory", theory "validated through revolutionary practice". ''[[Social Justice and the City]]'' (1973) expressed Harvey's position that geography could not remain 'objective' in the face of urban poverty and associated ills. It has been cited widely (over 6600 times, by 2017, in a discipline where 50 citations are rare), and it makes a significant contribution to Marxian theory by arguing that capitalism annihilates space to ensure its own [[social reproduction|reproduction]]. [[Dialectical materialism]] has guided his subsequent work, notably the theoretically sophisticated ''[[Limits to Capital]]'' (1982), which furthers the radical geographical analysis of capitalism, and several books on urban processes and urban life have followed it. ''[[The Condition of Postmodernity]]'' (1989), written while a Professor at [[University of Oxford|Oxford]], was a best-seller (the London ''[[The Independent]]'' named it as one of the fifty most important works of non-fiction to be published since 1945, and it is cited 30,000 times by 2017). It is a materialist critique of [[postmodernism|postmodern]] ideas and arguments, suggesting these actually emerge from contradictions within capitalism itself. ''[[Justice, Nature and the Geography of Difference]]'' (1996) focuses on [[social justice|social]] and [[environmental justice]] (although its dialectical perspective has attracted the ire of some Greens). ''[[Spaces of Hope]]'' (2000) has an utopian theme and indulges in speculative thinking about how an alternative world might look. His study of Second Empire Paris and the events surrounding the [[Paris Commune]] in ''[[Paris, Capital of Modernity]]'', is undoubtedly his most elaborated historical-geographical work. The onset of US military action since 2001 has provoked a blistering critique – in ''[[The New Imperialism]]'' (2003) he argues that the war in Iraq allows US neo-conservatives to divert attention from the failures of capitalism 'at home'. His next work, ''[[A Brief History of Neoliberalism]]'' (2005), provides an historical examination of the theory and divergent practices of neoliberalism since the mid-1970s. This work conceptualises the neoliberalised global [[political economy]] as a system that benefits few at the expense of many, and which has resulted in the (re)creation of class distinction through what Harvey calls "[[accumulation by dispossession]]". His book ''The Enigma of Capital'' (2010) takes a long view of the contemporary economic crisis. Harvey explains how capitalism came to dominate the world and why it resulted in the financial crisis. He describes that the essence of capitalism is its amorality and lawlessness and to talk of a regulated, ethical capitalism is to make a fundamental error.{{cite book |author=David Harvey |title=The enigma of capital: and the crises of capitalism |publisher=Profile Books |year=2010 |isbn=1-84765-201-8}} A series of events linked to this book across London academic forums, such as the LSE, proved hugely popular and sparked a new interest in Harvey's work. Harvey returned to Johns Hopkins from [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] in 1993, but spent increasing time elsewhere as a speaker and visitor, notably as a salaried Miliband Fellow at the [[London School of Economics]] in the late 1990s. In 1996, he delivered the [[Ellen Churchill Semple]] lecture at [[Department of Geography, University of Kentucky|UK Geography]].[http://geography.as.uky.edu/semple-day Ellen Churchill Semple Day] (accessed 30 June 2015) He moved to the [[City University of New York]] in 2001 as a Distinguished Professor, now residing in its Department of Anthropology. He has spent most of his academic career in Anglo-America, with brief sojourns in France and a range of foreign visiting appointments (currently as acting Advisory Professor at Tongji University in Shanghai). He has supervised many PhD students. Several of these, such as [[Neil Smith (geographer)|Neil Smith]], Richard Walker, [[Erik Swyngedouw]], Michael Johns, Maarten Hajer, Patrick Bond, Melissa Wright, and Greg Ruiters now hold or held important academic positions themselves. In 2013 Harvey was asked by the Republic of Ecuador to help set up the National Strategic Center for the Right to the Territory (CENEDET),CEDENET Ecuador [https://cenedet.wordpress.com/] which he directed with the urbanist [[Miguel Robles-Durán]] until its alleged forced closure in 2017. Critical response to Harvey's work has been sustained. In the early years, there was competition between Harvey and proponents of quantitative and non-politicized geography, notably [[Brian Berry]]. A recent critical appraisal (Castree & [[Derek Gregory|Gregory]], 2006) explores some critiques of Harvey in detail. ===Reading Marx's ''Capital''=== Two constants in Harvey's life and work have been teaching a course on Marx's ''Capital''Harvey, D. 2008 [http://davidharvey.org/ "Reading Marx's Capital"] An open course consisting of a close reading of the text of Marx's Capital Volume I in 13 video lectures by David Harvey. and his support for student activism and community and labour movements (notably in Baltimore). His course was put into a Youtube lecture series,https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gBazR59SZXk which gained immense popularity and resulted in two companion books for the two volumes of Marx's ''Capital''.{{cite book|last1=Harvey|first1=David|title=A Companion to Marx's Capital|date=2010|publisher=Verso Books|isbn=1844673596}} ==Recognition== David Harvey is widely recognized as a foundational scholar in [[urban geography]].Castree, N. and Gregory, D. eds., 2008. David Harvey: a critical reader. John Wiley & Sons. Harvey's books have been widely translated. He holds honorary doctorates from Roskilde (Denmark), Buenos Aires (Argentina), Faculty of Social Sciences at [[Uppsala University]]http://www.uu.se/en/about-uu/traditions/prizes/honorary-doctorates/ (Sweden), Ohio State University (USA), Lund University (Sweden) and the University of Kent (UK). Among other awards he has received the Anders Retzius Gold Medal of the [[Swedish Society for Anthropology and Geography]], the [[Gold Medal (RGS)|Patron's Medal]] of the [[Royal Geographical Society]] and the [[Lauréat Prix International de Géographie Vautrin Lud|Vautrin Lud International Prize]] in Geography (France). He was made a fellow of the [[British Academy]] in 1998, and was elected to the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 2007. He is a member of the Interim Committee for the emerging International Organization for a Participatory Society.'[http://www.iopsociety.org/interim-committee International Organization for a Participatory Society – Interim Committee] Retrieved 2012-3-31 ==Affiliated institutions== * B.A. (Hons) St Johns College, Cambridge, 1957 * PhD St Johns College, Cambridge, 1961. * Post-doc, University of Uppsala, Sweden 1960–1961 * Lecturer, Geography, University of Bristol, UK (1961–1969) * Associate Professor, Department of Geography and Environmental Engineering, Johns Hopkins University, (1969–1973) * Professor, Department of Geography and Environmental Engineering, Johns Hopkins University (1973–1987, and 1993–2001) * Halford Mackinder Professor of Geography, University of Oxford (1987–1993) * Distinguished Professor, Dept. of Anthropology, City University of New York (2001–present) ==Bibliography== {{Library resources box|by=yes|onlinebooks=yes|viaf=106978116}} * ''[[Explanation in Geography]]'' (1969) * ''[[Social Justice and the City]]'' (1973) * ''The Limits to Capital'' (1982) * ''The Urbanization of Capital (1985) * ''Consciousness and the Urban Experience'' (1985) * ''[[The Condition of Postmodernity: An Enquiry into the Origins of Cultural Change]]'' (1989) * ''The Urban Experience'' (1989) * Teresa Hayter, David Harvey (eds.) {{Multiple issues|{{primary sources|date=January 2016}}{{one source|date=January 2016}}}} {{Infobox government agency |name=Ministry of Defence of the Republic of Belarus |nativename_a=([[Russian language|Russian]]): Министерство обороны Республики Беларусь
([[Belarusian language]]): Мiнiстэрства абароны Рэспублікі Беларусь |nativename_r= |logo=Эмблема Министерства обороны Республики Беларусь.png |logo_caption=Emblem of the Armed Forces of Belarus |logo_width= |seal= |seal_width= |seal_caption= |image=МО РБ.jpg |image_caption=The building of ministry |formed={{start date and age|1992|03|20|df=y}} |dissolved= |superseding= |jurisdiction={{bulletedlist|[[Armed Forces of Belarus]]|[[Council of Ministers of the Republic of Belarus]]|[[Security Council of Belarus]]}} |headquarters=[[Minsk]], [[Belarus]] |employees= |budget= |minister1_name=Lieutenant General [[Andrei Ravkov]] |minister1_pfo=Minister of Defense |website={{url|http://www.mil.by}} |footnotes= |chief1_name=Major General [[Sergei Potapenko]] |chief1_position=Deputy Minister of Defense |chief2_name=Major-General [[Oleg Belokonev]] |chief2_position=[[General Staff of the Armed Forces of Belarus|Chief of the General Staff]] |chief3_name= |chief3_position= |chief4_name= |chief4_position= |chief5_name= |chief5_position= |chief6_name= |chief6_position= |chief7_name= |chief7_position= |chief8_name= |chief8_position= |chief9_name= |chief9_position= |parent_department={{bulletedlist|[[Ministry of Defense (Soviet Union)|Ministry of Defense of the Soviet Union]]|Headquarters of the [[Belorussian Military District]]}} }} The '''Ministry of Defence of the Republic of Belarus''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: Министерство обороны Республики Беларусь; [[Belarusian language]]: Мiнiстэрства абароны Рэспублікі Беларусь) is the government organisation that is charged with the duties of raising and maintaining the [[Armed Forces of Belarus]]. The formation of the ministry began in March 1992, after the events of 1991 in which the [[Soviet Union]] had effectively dissolved. The ministry was formed on the basis of the former Headquarters of the [[Soviet Army]]'s [[Belorussian Military District]]. Seven officers have served as Minister of Defence of Belarus: [[Petr Chaus]], [[Pavel Kozlovskii]], [[Anatoly Kostenko]],Yury Kasyanov, 'Maltsev's Reform,' NVO, No. 17, May 31–June 6, 2002, p.8. See also re Chaus, "Petr Chaus: schitayu, chto nam ne nuzhno …"', [[Krasnaya Zvezda]], 16 July 1992. [[Leonid Maltsev]] (1995–96), Colonel General [[Alexander Chumakov (general)|Alexander Chumakov]], a Russian officer, (1996–2001),Richard Woff, 'Minsk: making limited progress with reform,' [[Jane's Intelligence Review]], June 1996, 248. However, Woff dates Chumakov's appointment to 'late 1995.' [[Yuriy Zhadobin]] (2009–2014), and [[Andrei Ravkov]] (2014-present). The ministry is part of the [[Security Council of Belarus]], interdepartmental meeting with a mandate to ensure the security of the state. The [[President of Belarus|President]], currently [[Alexander Lukashenko]], appoints the Minister of Defense, who heads the ministry, as well as the heads of the armed services. These four appointees meet with the Secretary of the Security Council every two months. Security Council decisions are approved by a qualified majority of those present. Since 2014, the position of Minister of Defense has been fillef is currently filled by Lieutenant General [[Andrei Ravkov]]. ==Structure== The ministry is composed of five main directorates, two main departments, one minor department, an agency and General Staff. ==List of Ministers of Defense== * [[Peter Chaus|Pyotr Chavus]] (1992) * [[Pavel Pavlovich Kozlovsky|Pavel Kazlouski]] (1992-1994) * [[Anatoly Kostenko|Anatol Kastsenka]] (1994-1995) * [[Leonid Maltsev|Leanid Maltsau]] (first term, 1996) * [[Aleksandr Petrovich Chumakov|Alyaksandr Chumakou]] (1996-2001) * [[Leonid Maltsev|Leanid Maltsau]] (second term, 2001-2009) * [[Yuri Zhadobin|Yury Zhadobin]] (2009-2014) * [[Andrei Ravkov|Andrei Raukou]] (2014-present) ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.mil.by/by/ Website of the Ministry of Defence of Belarus] *[http://belarusdigest.com/story/belaruss-new-military-doctrine-what%E2%80%99s-message-27047/ Belarus's New Military Doctrine: What’s The Message?] {{beldef}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Belarus, Defense Ministry of}} [[Category:1992 establishments in Belarus]] [[Category:Defence ministers of Belarus]] [[Category:Defence ministries]] [[Category:Government ministries of Belarus|Defense]]

{{nofootnotes|date=September 2009}} '''ESDS Government''' is a national data service which provides large-scale government surveys, such as the [[General Household Survey]] and the [[Labour Force Survey]], as well as other key data resources for understanding population structure and change in the UK and its constituent countries. It is jointly funded by the [[Economic and Social Research Council]] (ESRC) and the [[Joint Information Systems Committee]] (JISC).
In July 2012, the ESRC announced that all of ESDS will join the UK Data Service, to be established as of October 1, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=New national digital repository for social and economic data|url=http://www.esrc.ac.uk/news-and-events/press-releases/22231/new-national-digital-repository-for-social-and-economic-data.aspx|publisher=Economic and Social Data Service|accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref>
==Service overview==
Some examples of the research supported by the surveys include:
* resources, health and living conditions of older people * ethnic differences in family and household composition * patterns of consumption, including drinking and smoking * gender and ethnic differences in employment earnings * lifestyle, consumption and health patterns * social capital and its relationship to health, employment and earnings * comparisons across different UK regions and across different time periods
ESDS Government is led by the [[Cathie Marsh Centre for Census and Survey Research]] (CCSR) and provides user support, facilitates user meetings on specific surveys, organises training courses on topics of interest, on specific statistical software packages and on statistical analysis methods as well as provides topic-related online course materials and a range of teaching datasets.
One of the central aims of the service is to promote and facilitate increased and more effective use of government datasets in research, learning and teaching across a range of disciplines.
The acquisition, processing and delivery of the large-scale government datasets under this service is undertaken by the [[UK Data Archive]]. Data is available both via download and online exploration and visualisation via [http://nesstar.esds.ac.uk/webview/index.jsp Nesstar].
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox political party | colorcode = #1B4D3E | name = Farmers' Assemblies | native_name = Põllumeeste Kogud | logo = Põllumeeste Kogud clover, 1934.svg | president = [[Konstantin Päts]] | founder = | foundation = 1917 | dissolution = 1935 | split = | successor = | headquarters = | ideology = [[Agrarianism]]
[[Conservatism]]
[[Anti-communism]] | position = [[Right-wing]] | national = | newspaper = | colours = {{Color box|#1B4D3E}} [[Green]] | flag = Põllumeeste Kogud flag, 1934.svg | country = Estonia }} The '''Farmers' Assemblies''' ({{lang-et|Põllumeeste Kogud}}) was a conservative political party in [[Estonia]]. Led by [[Konstantin Päts]], it was the ruling party for most of the inter-war period. ==History== The '''Rural League''' (''Maarahva Liit'') was formed in 1917 following an article in the ''[[Postimees]]'' newspaper by members of the Southern Estonian Farmers' Central Society, which called for the rural population to form political groups to represent themselves.Vincent E McHale (1983) ''Political parties of Europe'', Greenwood Press, p378 {{ISBN|0-313-23804-9}} The new party published the ''Maaliit'' newspaper. In the [[Estonian Provincial Assembly election, 1917|Provincial Assembly elections]] later in the year the League received 22% of the vote and emerged as the largest party in the Assembly, holding 13 of the 62 seats.{{cite book |title=The Revenge of the Past |last=Suny |first=Ronald Grigor |page=54 |year=1993 |publisher= |location= |isbn=978-0-8047-2247-6 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-4efW7SvG0YC&pg=PA54 }} After the elections the party became part of the [[Democratic Bloc (Estonia)|Democratic Bloc]] alongside the [[Estonian Democratic Party]] and the [[Estonian Radical Democratic Party]]. The Bloc received around 23% of the vote in the February 1918 [[Estonian Constituent Assembly election, 1918|Constituent Assembly elections]], which was cancelled. At the time the League was considering inviting the [[German Army (German Empire)|German Army]] to occupy Estonia to ward off Russian Bolsheviks. [[Konstantin Päts]] then joined the League to prevent this idea being implemented, and became its leader. In the [[Estonian Constituent Assembly election, 1919|1919 Constituent Assembly elections]], the League performed poorly, winning only eight of the 120 seats and finishing in fourth place. The [[Estonian Labour Party]] government subsequently enacted radical land reforms that redistributed land to landless farmers. This policy was opposed by the Rural League, who saw a large increase in support in the [[Estonian parliamentary election, 1920|1920 elections]] amongst the new landowners who had drifted to the right following their gains. The results saw the League finish second with 21 of the 100 seats in the [[Riigikogu]], and Päts became [[Head of State of Estonia|Head of State]]. In 1921 the party was reorganised, and renamed the '''Farmers' Assemblies''', with the ''Maaliit'' newspaper renamed ''Kaja''.McHale, p379 In 1923 a split saw some liberal members leave the party to form the [[Settlers' Party]]. The [[Estonian parliamentary election, 1923|1923 elections]] saw the party become the largest in the Riigikogu, winning 23 seats. Päts remained Head of State. The [[Estonian parliamentary election, 1926|1926 elections]] saw the party retain its 23 seats. Although the [[Estonian Socialist Workers' Party]] become the largest faction in the Riigikogu, Farmers' Assemblies member [[Jaan Teemant]] remained Head of State, having taken office in December 1925. The party remained the second largest faction in the Riigikogu following the [[Estonian parliamentary election, 1929|1929 elections]], in which it won 24 seats.[[Dieter Nohlen]] & Philip Stöver (2010) ''Elections in Europe: A data handbook'', p586 {{ISBN|978-3-8329-5609-7}} However, [[Otto Strandman]] of the [[Estonian Labour Party|Labour Party]] was able to form a government. Prior to the [[Estonian parliamentary election, 1932|1932 elections]] the party merged with the [[Settlers' Party]] to form the [[Union of Settlers and Smallholders]],Nohlen & Stöver, p579 with the new party winning 42 of the 100 seats.Nohlen & Stöver, p587 In 1933 a large conservative faction of the Farmers' Assemblies left the Union to re-establish the party. All parties were banned on 6 March 1935,McHale, p371 but during the Soviet occupation the party continued in exile in [[Sweden]].McHale, p380 ==References== {{reflist}} {{Estonian political parties}} [[Category:Conservative parties in Estonia]] [[Category:Defunct political parties in Estonia]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1917]] [[Category:1917 establishments in Estonia]] [[Category:Agrarian parties]] [[Category:1935 disestablishments in Estonia]]

{{Infobox legislature | name = Federal National Assembly | native_name = مجلس الامة الاتحادي | native_name_lang = Arabic | transcription_name = | legislature = | coa_pic = | coa_res = | coa_alt = | coa_caption = | logo_pic = | logo_res = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | house_type = | body = | jurisdiction = | houses = | term_limits = | foundation = 1972 | disbanded = 1976 | preceded_by = | succeeded_by = | new_session = | leader1_type = Speaker | leader1 = Dr. Kheiri el-Saghir Abu Laqma, [[Bashir al-Rabiti]] | party1 = | election1 = | leader2_type = | leader2 = | party2 = | election2 = | leader3_type = | leader3 = | party3 = | election3 = | leader4_type = | leader4 = | party4 = | election4 = | leader5_type = | leader5 = | party5 = | election5 = | leader6_type = | leader6 = | party6 = | election6 = | leader7_type = | leader7 = | party7 = | election7 = | seats = 60 | house1 = | house2 = | structure1 = | structure1_res = | structure1_alt = | structure2 = | structure2_res = | structure2_alt = | political_groups1 = | political_groups2 = | committees1 = | committees2 = | joint_committees = | term_length = | authority = | salary = | seats1_title = | seats1 = | seats2_title = | seats2 = | seats3_title = | seats3 = | seats4_title = | seats4 = | seats5_title = | seats5 = | seats6_title = | seats6 = | seats7_title = | seats7 = | seats8_title = | seats8 = | voting_system1 = | voting_system2 = | last_election1 = | last_election2 = | last_election3 = | next_election1 = | next_election2 = | next_election3 = | redistricting = | motto = | session_room = | session_res = | session_alt = | meeting_place = | session_room2 = | session_res2 = | session_alt2 = | meeting_place2 = | website = <!--{{URL|www.example.com}}--> | constitution = | footnotes = }} The '''Federal National Assembly''' ({{lang-ar|مجلس الامة الاتحادي}}) was the parliament of the [[Federation of Arab Republics]].
The assembly included representatives from [[Egypt]], [[Libya]] and [[Syria]].<ref name="a"/><ref>{{cite book|title=MEN Economic Weekly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bc4MAQAAMAAJ|edition=36-44|volume=15|year=1976|publisher=Middle East News Agency|page=2}}</ref> The assembly was responsible for examine and ratify legislation for the Federation, approve budget and ratify treaties.<ref name="c"/>
Each of the member republics was represented by 20 members in the Federal National Assembly, elected amongst the members of its People's Assembly.<ref name="a"/><ref>{{cite book|title=African Recorder|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6i5wAAAAMAAJ|volume=11|year=1972|publisher=M. H. Samuel|page=3076}}</ref> Members were elected on four year mandates.<ref name="c"/> Members elected had to resign from their mandates in their republican parliaments.<ref name="c"/> The Federal National Assembly met twice a year, opening its inaugural session on March 12, 1972 and holding its last session in October 1975.<ref name="a"/><ref name="Limited1978">{{cite book|author=Europa Publications Limited|title=The Middle East and North Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rzNXAAAAMAAJ|volume=25|year=1978|publisher=Europa Publications|isbn=978-0-905118-23-9|page=154}}</ref> The sessions lasted for three months.<ref name="c">{{cite book|title=International Enclopedia of Comparative Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qdFGLppsxcEC&pg=SL21-PA12|publisher=BRILL|pages=U–12|id=GGKEY:X430UFATXKY}}</ref>
==Elections== The People's Assembly of Egypt elected the 20 members Egyptian members of the Federal National Assembly.<ref name="b"/> One of the elected members was Dr. Abdul Hamid Hassan, former student union leader and member of the [[Arab Socialist Union (Egypt)|Arab Socialist Union]] Central Committee.<ref name="Tajir1978">{{cite book|author=Sayed Mohamed Mahdi al Tajir|title=The International Who's who of the Arab World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BYq5AAAAIAAJ|year=1978|publisher=International Who's Who of the Arab World Limited|page=227}}</ref>
The Libyan members were elected by popular vote on March 5, 1972, some 500,000 cast their votes.<ref name="b">{{cite book|title=Record of the Arab World: Yearbook of Arab and Israeli Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qB5BAQAAIAAJ|volume=2|year=1972|publisher=Research and Publishing House.|pages=849-850}}</ref> The vote had been scheduled for February 27, 1972 but was postponed as new requirements for candidates were introduced.<ref name="b"/><ref name="NyropStudies1973">{{cite book|author1=Richard F. Nyrop|author2=American University (Washington, D.C.). Foreign Area Studies|author3=Stanford Research Institute|title=Area handbook for Libya|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PUlk3hsvMkIC|year=1973|publisher=U.S. Govt. Print. Off.|page=160}}</ref> As per the requirements from the law from February 27 candidates were required to be Libyan citizens, hold a secondary education certificate, be 30 years old, hold membership in the [[Arab Socialist Union (Libya)|Arab Socialist Union]] and deposit 50 [[Libyan dinar]]s (most of these requirements were added ad hoc after the postponing of the vote in February 1972).<ref name="b"/> Voting was compulsory.<ref name="b"/>
The election result was declared on March 7, 1972 by Minister of Interior Major Abd ul-Mumim al-Huni.<ref name="NyropStudies1973"/> The 20 members elected from Libya were Bashir Muhammad al-Rabiti, Al-Taher Salam Kridan, Ali Mustapha al-Misrati, Milad Mohammad Ali al-Oud, Milad Ali Muhammad Abu Amjat, Hassan Abd ul-Hafiz al-Jihani, Khalifa abd ul-Matlub Yunus al-Warfali, Saleh Massoud Bouisir, Dr. Kheiri el-Saghir Abu Laqma, Abdullah al-Hush Abdullah, Ammar Ahmad al-Sa'adi, Mohammad Issa Yehiya al-Barouni, Ali Mustapa Mazak Kadad, Ibrahim Obayd Sa'id, Abbas Mohammad Abd un-Nabi al-Qadiri, Abdus Salam Mohammad ben Nur, Mohammad al-Hazmi Saleh al-Trahouni, Maatuq Mohammad Maatuq al-Zubeidi, Maftah Mohammad bin Issa and Ali Senoussi Abd us-Said al-Mansouri.<ref name="b"/><ref>Eastlaws. [http://site.eastlaws.com/GeneralSearch/Home/ArticlesTDetails?MasterID=1261253 بشأن النتيجة العامة لانتخابات مجلس الأمة الاتحادي]<!-- These were four names I could extract with snippet view, all 20 should be found there --></ref><ref name="يوسف2008">{{cite book|author=مقريف، محمد يوسف|title=ليبيا من الشرعية الدستورية إلى الشرعية الثورية: دراسة توثيقية تحليلية|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AVYOAQAAMAAJ|year=2008|publisher=دار الاستقلال}}</ref>
==Speaker== Dr. Kheiri el-Saghir Abu Laqma of Libya was elected as the speaker of the Federal National Assembly, <ref name="a">{{cite book|title=Political Handbook and Atlas of the World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ia8bAQAAMAAJ|year=1973|publisher=Council on Foreign Relations|page=35}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Middle East News Economic Weekly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dMoMAQAAMAAJ|year=1972|publisher=Middle East News|page=2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=MEED Arab Report|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zalVAAAAYAAJ|year=1976|publisher=Middle East Economic Digest Limited|page=634}}</ref> In his inaugural speech in March 1972 Abu Laqma hailed the Federation of Arab Republics as a step towards [[Pan-Arabism|Pan-Arab unity]].<ref name="al-Awsaṭ1972">{{cite book|author=Anbāʾ al-Sharq al-Awsaṭ|title=MEN Middle East News Economic Weekly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IQoMAQAAMAAJ|edition=10-18|volume=11|date=March 1972|publisher=Middle East News Agency|page=4}}</ref> Abu Laqma was later replaced by fellow Libyan [[Bashir al-Rabiti]] as speaker of the assembly.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Middle East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PgAVAQAAMAAJ|edition=87–98|year=1982|publisher=International Communications|page=9}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Maghreb, Machrek|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oCQOAQAAMAAJ|edition=61-66|year=1974|publisher=La Documentation française|page=54}}</ref>
==Disbanding== The last session was held in October 1975. The March 1976 session was postponed indefinitely.<ref name="Limited1978"/>
==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Federation of Arab Republics]] [[Category:Historical legislatures]] [[Category:Supranational legislatures]] [[Category:1972 establishments in Africa]] [[Category:1976 disestablishments in Africa]]
